subsections.title: What is Java?
subsections.content: Java is a general-purpose, class-based, object-oriented programming language designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible.

keyPoints.label: Secure
keyPoints.description: Built-in security features and no direct memory access

keyPoints.label: Compiled and Interpreted
keyPoints.description: Java code is compiled to bytecode and interpreted by JVM

subsections.title: Java Architecture
subsections.content: Source Code (.java) → Java Compiler (javac) → Bytecode (.class) → JVM (Java Virtual Machine) → Operating System → Hardware Execution

subsections.title: Minimal Java Program
subsections.explanation:
Breaking Down the Code:
- public: Access modifier (visible everywhere)
- class: Keyword to define a class
- HelloWorld: Class name (must match filename)
- static: Method belongs to class, not instance
- void: Method returns nothing
- main(): Entry point of program
- String[] args: Command-line arguments
- System.out.println(): Print to console with newline

subsections.title: Type Casting
subsections.explanation: Implicit casting is like upgrading (always safe). Explicit casting is like downgrading (might lose data).

subsections.title: Arithmetic Operators
subsections.code:
int a = 10, b = 3;
int sum = a + b;        // 13
int diff = a - b;       // 7
int product = a * b;    // 30
int quotient = a / b;   // 3
int remainder = a % b;  // 1

subsections.title: Logical Operators
subsections.code:
boolean a = true, b = false;
a && b;   // false (AND)
a || b;   // true (OR)
!a;       // false (NOT)

interviewQuestions.question: What are the differences between Stack and Heap memory?
interviewQuestions.answer: Stack stores primitive values and references (thread-safe). Heap stores objects (shared by threads).

interviewQuestions.question: Explain == vs .equals()
interviewQuestions.answer: == compares reference, .equals() compares content. Use .equals() for strings.

interviewQuestions.question: What is autoboxing and unboxing?
interviewQuestions.answer: Autoboxing converts primitive to wrapper (int → Integer). Unboxing converts wrapper to primitive.

interviewQuestions.question: What are the 4 pillars of OOP?
Can you override a static method?
interviewQuestions.answer: No, static methods cannot be overridden.

interviewQuestions.question: What's the difference between ArrayList and LinkedList?
interviewQuestions.answer: ArrayList uses array (O(1) access). LinkedList uses linked list (O(1) insertion).

interviewQuestions.question: Why is HashMap not thread-safe?
interviewQuestions.answer: HashMap allows concurrent modification. Use ConcurrentHashMap for thread safety.
